Question: With a _______ Tabular Editor 3 license, you can connect to a remote dataset in Power BI Premium Capacity
Context: An Enterprise license is required to connect to a remote dataset in Premium Capacity.

Question: With a _______ Tabular Editor 3 license, you can connect to a remote dataset in Power BI Premium Per User
Context: An Enterprise license is required to connect to a remote dataset in Premium Capacity.

Question: Tabular Editor 3 cannot open _____ file types.
Context: While Tabular Editor can open .pbit files (as they contain metadata information), it is not supported. Tabular Editor cannot open .pbix files.

Question: What operating system does Tabular Editor run on?
Context: Tabular Editor is a Windows application.

Question: True or False: To use Tabular Editor for Tabular Modeling, you need an internet connection.
PossibleAnswers: True - You need it to edit Data Models in Power BI Service
False - Tabular Editor only connects to Power BI Desktop as an External Tool
False - Tabular Editor is an Offline Tool
True - Tabular Editor needs it to format DAX.
Context: Tabular Editor can edit remote data models, but doesn't need to. You can work entirely offline, connected to model metadata or a local Power BI Desktop model.
Answer: False - Tabular Editor is an Offline Tool

Question: Which of the following data modeling features are possible to configure in Tabular Editor but not Power BI Desktop?
Context: Some features do not have a user interface in Power BI Desktop, but are supported modeling operations. All of these are examples of powerful data modeling features which cannot be configured from Power BI Desktop.

Question: To benefit most from 'Personalize Visuals' in Power BI, you need to configure ______ in Tabular Editor, because it cannot be configured from Power BI Desktop.
Context: Adding fields to perspectives and then enabling 'Personalize Visuals' limits the fields exposed to end-users. Creating tailored perspectives for specific report pages can be very valuable.

Question: True or False: Tabular Editor is intended for only enterprise Tabular Model developers.
PossibleAnswers: True: Tabular Editor is too complex for Analysts.
True: Tabular Editor is meant for Enterprise model development.
False: Tabular Editor can also be helpful for Analysts and Support engineers to analyze models.
False: Tabular Editor can be used also to all dataset types.
Context: Tabular Editor can bring value to all personas creating datasets and Tabular Models. It helps you make better models, faster.
Answer: False: Tabular Editor can also be helpful for Analysts and Support engineers to analyze models.

Question: Can you add new Excel data sources stored in SharePoint with Tabular Editor?
PossibleAnswers: Yes, you can add them by creating data tables and new M Partitions, then specifying the M code for the data connection and transformation.
No, SharePoint is not a supported data source.
Yes, you can use the 'Import Data Tables' to add it.
No, you cannot add new data sources with Tabular Editor, only modify DAX code.
Context: You can add any data source supported by the service. Supported sources by Tabular Editor are merely easier as the user interface will generate the M code for you, or add the explict source to the model.
Answer: Yes, you can add them by creating data tables and new M Partitions, then specifying the M code for the data connection and transformation.

Question: Which of the below features are not in Tabular Editor
PossibleAnswers: Preview data tables to view transactional data
Batch rename children to rename many model objects at once
DAX Debugger to break up complex DAX evaluations and navigate through each step
DAX Queries to query the model and show how long the query took to evaluate.
Context: All of the above are features of Tabular Editor. You can not only use it to help you write better DAX, but also add or manage data sources and Power Query, create/change relationships, test / validate the model, and perform complex automations, among other things.

Question: In Tabular Editor, you can test RLS using ______
Context: Impersonation lets you run a query and view it as a user who has Build permissions, access to the dataset, and has been assigned to a security role. This works with DAX Queries, Pivot Grids and Preview Data.

Question: What is the easiest way to view the Power Query of an Incremental Refresh table from Tabular Editor?
PossibleAnswers: When selecting the Table, in the 'Properties' pane, under 'Source Expression'
When selecting the Table, in the 'Properties' pane, under 'Polling Expression'
When selecting the Table, in the 'Expression Editor' pane, in the top-left, click on the Drop-Down that says 'Default Detail-Rows Expression' and select 'Source Expression'
When selecting the M Expression, look at the 'Expression Editor' pane to see the M code.
Context: The 'Source Expression' is the main 'Power Query' for the Incremental Refresh table. It can be viewed from the 'Properties' pane, but it is better to view it in the 'Expression Editor'.
Answer: When selecting the M Expression, look at the 'Expression Editor' pane to see the M code.

Question: When you edit the Power Query of a table to add or remove columns, what is the easiest way to modify the schema of the model table to add these columns?
PossibleAnswers: Right-click the table and select 'Update Table Schema...'
Add the data columns to the table and update their 'Source Column' property
Duplicate an existing column and change the 'Lineage Tag' property
Context: The 'Update Table Schema' property will automatically update the schema, adding or removing any columns. This can be done manually, by deleting the columns or manually adding them and updating the 'Source Column' property. The 'Lineage Tag' must always be unique; Tabular Editor already ensures this is the case behind-the-scenes, so you don't have to modify it, yourself.
Answer: When selecting the M Expression, look at the 'Expression Editor' pane to see the M code.

Question: The easiest way to format ALL DAX in a model is with ______
Context: DAX Scripts let you edit multiple DAX objects at once. This lets you format all DAX in one, clean sweep.

Question: You can edit a DAX expression and Format String at the same time in Tabular Editor using ______
Context: DAX Scripts let you edit multiple properties of the DAX object at once.
